annotation-spec.doc: This annotation specification was specifically developed to code postural/gestural events from TV session of the "Literarisches Quartett" where four literary critics discuss a number of recently published books. This scheme is thus suited for a group of sitting people where the seating facillities are immobile.

valueset.name: deicticType
valueset.value-el:
addressee
Subject points to addressed person/object.

space
Subject points somewhere in gesture space, points to nothing concrete that is present in the room.

self
Subject points to him/herself usually by putting the hand on his/her chest.

person
A present person other than the speaker or addressee.

audience
Points at audience, usually in a circumscribing motion.

self+addressee
Points to himself and to addressee.

valueset.name: phaseType
valueset.value-el:
prep
Preparation phase, bringing arm and hand into stroke position. Note that changing hand shape before/after moving the arm belongs to the preparation, too. Also code position info.

stroke
The most energetic part of the gesture movement. Encode all other attributes for this gesture phrase in the stroke element!

beats
Only for non-beat gestures! A number of successive strokes (beats); all strokes should be covered by this phase. If there is a hold in-between then continue with prep.

hold
A phase of stillness just before or just after the stroke, usually used to defer the stroke so that it coincides with a certain word. When annotating an element as "hold" do not annotate any other attributes!

recoil
Directly after the stroke the hand may spring back so as to emphasize the harshness of the stroke.

retract
Retraction. Movement back to rest position. In sitting position this is usually the arm rest, the lap or folded arms. Encode no other attributes in a "retract" element.

partial-retract
Retraction movement that is stopped midway to open another gesture phrase. Code position info here.

valueset.name: emblemType
valueset.value-el:
anticipation
Anticipation of evil or warning or threat. Open hand waving near own head/ear as if preparing to slap someone. Verbalization: "Oh wait!", "I see it coming", "O my!"

attention
Index finger held motionless in the air to emphasize the importance of what is said, seen or heard. (German: "erhobener Zeigefinger").

block
A gesture of total refusal ("No way!"), blocking suggestions/arguments made or expected ("No matter what, I don't accept/believe/do this."). Usually, palm toward addressee, moving like along a wall in front of the speaker either with palm facing the addressee or with index finger.

chide
A gesture of warning ("watch out!"), reprimand ("That was bad of you!") or attention ("Note this!"). Usually done with outstretched index finger wiggling in the air.

concession
A gesture of partial concession ("You are right but..."), pre-emptive defence ("I know you won't like this but...") or pre-emptive pacification ("I don't mean to disrespect your opinion but..."). Movement usually consists of showing the insides of your hands (palm down), like in a "hands up" gesture of surrender (defensiveness!).

despair-threat
Display of exaggerated despair or threat by lifting both arms with elbows out and fingertips almost touching the forehead. Verbalization: "what am I to do!", "jesus!", "this is so bad!". Often ironically used: "o yes, this is soooo bad!" - implying that someone overreacted.

doubt-shrug
A gesture indicating doubt ("I wouldn't count on that."), ignorance ("I don't know.") or indifference ("I don't care."). Movement consists of showing the insides of your hands (palm up) and is usually accompanying by a raising of the shoulders (shrug).

dismiss
A gesture like waving off a little boy or a pet, like haughtily dismissing a submitted person. As opposed to dump, more like waving off a little annoyance (a fly) without much emotional display (rather disgust than anger).

finger-ring
A sign where the index finger meets the thumb, other fingers spread out or relaxed, usually signalling fine quality, good taste etc. In a more metaphoric sense it means that the matter is very subtle, that the reasoning is very precise/sharp. Note that the same gesture is used by conductors.

hand-clap
One hand slaps the other hand from. Verbalization: "What luck!", "well, now!", "good!", "so...".

hand-rub
One hand rubs the other hand.

hands-up
Both hands are raised, palms facing front. Literally taken, a gesture of surrender, showing lack of weapons (nothing to hide) and opening up body.

indignation
Both arms are raised, hands open, palms upwards. Shoulders are up and tense, and the face displays anger. Verbalization: "O come on!", "Now pull yourself together, will ya!". The gesture indicates one's losing temper/patience, as if provoked by a child's constant hassling.

invitation
Both arms are opened wide, hands open with palms towards addressee(s). Verbalization: "Welcome!", "You are invited to...", "I have nothing to hide". A gesture demonstrating cooperation, open-mindedness, open-heartedness, opening of one's own defences and innocence.

knee-slap
Hand(s) are slapped on knee(s) to signal something envigorating happening or incite other people to be active. Verbalization: "let's go", "well, now!", "good!", "so...". Variant: one hand slaps the other hand from high above (not like normal clapping) - looks like the knee version, only that one hand replaces the knee.

more-or-less
Hand(s) wiggles, palm down, eyes are slits to indicate an effort to estimate something. Verbalization: "more or less", "about/around", "approximately".

number
Fingers indicate a number. One finger (thumb or index finger) indicates number one, two fingers indicate number two etc.

one-hand-other-hand
Verbalization: "on one hand... on the other hand". Usually motioning with hand, fist, finger, arm in one direction, then in the other.

pray
Verbalization: "please" or "God/Heavens! Please!". Usually putting both hands together either flat or locked, still or shaking, eyes raised to heaven (or superior).

purse
Referring to hand shape: index finger and thumb touch and point upward, hand performing an up-and-down movement. Meaning is culture specific. In LitQua used for emphasis. Verbalization: "Ey!", "Hey!".

quivering-doubt
Hand, palm down, quivers a little from side to side to negate something or express doubt. Verbalization: "don't know", "not at all", "that's not right", "not exactly".

refusal
Verbalization: "no, thanks", "no", "really not". Waving hand/palm/index finger toward addressee, usually at a low level and with low intensity. Refusing idea, proposal, offer with a certain amount of politeness but can look condescending.

so-what
Signalling the provocation for an answer from a (possibly imaginary) interlocutor which obviously cannot be given because the answer is insinuated to be absurd/incredible/childish. Verbalized as "So what!" or just "So...?". Often performed by showing the palms and shaking the head with raised eyebrows. When used while recounting something it indicates that the content is trivial or obvious or blurry. Verbalizations: "or something like this", "or God knows..."

two-sided-doubt
Signalling that something (a) may not be right, or (b) is subtly two-sided. Performed by showing palm up and then turning the hand that palm is down, and then flipping back and forth. Verbalization: (a) "I don't know", "rather not" (b) "pretty complicated", "not that easy".

wipe
A gesture intending to stop something/one ("Let's end this"), indicating a break ("He stopped doing it.") or signalling dismission ("Let's forget about it"). Movement parallel to the floor like wiping a table.

wave
A gesture for getting attention, with open relaxed hand(s), palm towards addressee/audience. Verbalization: "hey!", "here!", "look here!"

valueset.name: metaphoricType
valueset.value-el:
conduit
The actual object or idea is treated as a material substance that can be presented in a cupped hand or as a larger object held with two hands.

conduit-emerge
A movement indicating a substance coming up, breaking through a surface upward. Hands usually dig somewhere and mimic throwing it in the air. This is not a "change" metaphoric, though if this movement were to be continued it could become one. So this one halts abruptly.

conduit-fling
Metaphoric object is thrown with some power at the final place. Refers to the motion of the gesture. Note that this motion includes the RELEASE of the conduit object, i.e. an actual object would fall to the floor. Otherwise, it is a normal conduit.

conduit-flip
Hand(s) indicate(s) that the substantialized topic is suddenly brought up/presented by showing the palm (presenting the topic/item) in a flipping movement. Very frequent. Unclear whether this should be treated as a beat.

conduit-fitting
A movement that indicates that the subject fits together or does not fit together. A substance is shown and a movement of compressing the substance is performed.

conduit-snatch
Metaphoric object is snatched out of the air like an insect und often held for same time.

conduit-sphere
Movement indicates a spherical shape. Usually performed when taking a wider perspective, talking about a "whole".

clockwork
Mental processes are seen as a clockwork with wheels, one of which is turned by a gesture close to the head with one or both hands.

beam
Stems from the idea that a gaze is like a beam originating from one's eyes.

bridge
Finger or hand makes a curved line like a bridge. Refers to a logical step or the next item in a sequence.

change
Usually circular, rotating movement indicating change or progress.

heart
Usually a shovelling motion like shoving a substance from the heart region to the surface. Referring to emotional states.

hold
A motion of grabbing a bell-jar (Käseglocke) like thing which encompasses the subject at hand. Is actually a conduit.

idea
Motion indicating an idea springing from one's (fore)head, done with a finger or a hand (or two).

aura
Hand indicate a spherical aura around one's head or body. Refers to processes of the mind like thinking, wondering, non-understanding, madness.

valueset.name: iconicType
valueset.value-el:
planarPF
Movement on the plane that is parallel to the speaker's front, i.e. the plane defined by a wall standing in front of the speaker.

planarPFloor
Movement on the plane that is parallel to the floor.

big
Hands indicate large size of an object/concept.

drink
Hands act as if bringing a glass to the lips in order to drink.

explosion
Hands fly in different directions to depict something big, forceful, incredible, great.

sway
Hands go up and down, each in turn, e.g. left up, right down.

small
Using index finger and thumb to show small distance.

strength
Making fists to express aggression, force, strength.

valueset.name: headshiftType
valueset.value-el:
sideways
Tilting (German: kippen) the head toward one side.

turn
Rotation of the head. Do not confuse with rotation of the body! A good indicator for the initiation of a head turn is an eye-blink.

nod
This is an emblem. It is therefore distinguished from a mere raise-lower sequence by assuming the intention to nod.

shake
Also an emblem. Therefore distinguished from a mere turn-turn sequence by assuming the intention to shake.

valueset.name: rstdirType
valueset.value-el:
backward
Marked span is related to previous span.

forward
Marked span is related to following span.

track-spec.name: take
track-spec.doc: This track records the take, i.e. the view of the camera on the scene. I use this track to see where the speaker of interest is not in the picture, i.e. in a file where Reich-Ranicki is of interest I will only annotate those takes where RR in not in the picture.

attribute.name: visible
attribute.doc: The actual person/group seen in the take.
attribute.value-el: Reich-Ranicki Also known as: the Pope of literary critique.

all
Panoramic view on all four speakers.

track-spec.name: trl
track-spec.doc: This track contains the transliteration of the spoken discourse. The token attribute contains the word or sound uttered. There are a number of special marks signified by squared brackets like [breath] or [aeh] for the mark-up of nonverbal sounds. Note that there is no syllable information.

attribute.name: emphasis
attribute.doc: Emphasis of this word. Possible values are the same as in SABLE.

group.name: ling
group.doc: Groups all tracks with linguistic information. The tracks typically refer to the trl track.

track-spec.name: i-phrase
track-spec.doc: Models the intonation phrase. This is a very fine segmentation employed here taking into account different features to identify a border (consult Stefan Baumann for details).

attribute.name: type
attribute.doc: There are different recurring patterns in the intonation contour and other, more technically oriented, distinctions. This dimension mixes some aspects but is still informative.
attribute.value-el:
copy
The intonational contour of the preceding intonational phrase is reused for effect.

track-spec.name: rst
track-spec.doc: Shows Rhetorical Relations coded with Mick O'Donnel's tool and imported here. The hierarchy is flattened, the direction indicates whether the current span was related to a previous or a following span.

attribute.name: relation1
attribute.doc: Relation that is closer to the leafs of the RST tree. This relation has therefore more relevance to this particular span.

attribute.name: direction1
attribute.doc: Tells which direction in the known RST scheme this relation is pointing to.

attribute.name: relation2
attribute.doc: This relation is higher up in the tree, i.e. closer to the root. Its meaning may therefore be more abstract (and hidden?).

attribute.name: direction2
attribute.doc: Tells which direction in the known RST scheme this relation is pointing to.

group.name: gesture
group.doc: This group clusters all so-called gestures which are really arm and hand gestures. The members of this group give a functional view on gesture. Overlap is only possible with beats that can occur in any type of gesture. Look at description of phase values to see how that is coded.

attribute.name: type
attribute.doc: My phase description is based on the phases postulated by Kendon and McNeill (1992), later on extended by Kita et al. (1999).
